nodes.id: FIRST PUBLICATION OF A CHRISTMAS CAROL
nodes.description: "The initial publication of the book 'A Christmas Carol' in 1915 by J. B. Lippincott Company, Philadelphia and New York."
"Cornhill represents the location where Bob Cratchit slides down twenty times, celebrating Christmas Eve."<SEP>"Place where Bob Cratchit went down a slide on Christmas Eve."
"Laundry establishment run by Mrs. Dilber."

"Marley is mentioned as being dead for seven years and served as Mr. Scrooge's partner in his business before he died."<SEP>"Marley is mentioned as having been dead for seven years and previously a partner in Scrooge's business before his death."<SEP>"Marley was a deceased partner of Scrooge, symbolizing the end of a business partnership."

"Scrooge is a character who shows animosity towards Christmas celebrations."<SEP>"Scrooge is a character who values work and money, showing a disdain for the holiday spirit."<SEP>"Scrooge is portrayed as someone who values work over the Christmas spirit and resents others for their festive demeanor."<SEP>"Scrooge is the main character, portrayed as an unfeeling, miserly, and unsympathetic individual who cares little for others' feelings or needs."<SEP>"Scrooge is the sole executor and administrator of his deceased partner Marley's affairs."
"The mention of a door-nail serves as an analogy to describe the solidity and permanence of Scrooge's own legacy."
"The funeral of Marley serves as the pivotal moment that brings Scrooge to a realization about his own mortality."

"Scrooge and Marley refers to the firm that existed due to the partnership between Scrooge and his deceased partner Marley."<SEP>"Scrooge and Marley was a business partnership that existed due to the legacy of both partners."
"The setting for a hypothetical incident involving an old man walking in the wind at night after dark, symbolizing Scrooge's existential crisis."
"The mention of Hamlet's father is part of a hypothetical scenario in which Marley serves as a cautionary figure for Scrooge."
"Marley's death serves as a turning point in Scrooge's life, leading him to reflect on his own mortality and actions."
"The old sinner is a character described as covetous and hard-bitten."

"Christmas Eve is described as cold and foggy weather with poor visibility and limited daylight hours."<SEP>"Christmas Eve is the event celebrated by participants like Bob Cratchit who enjoy sliding down Cornhill as a festive activity."<SEP>"Christmas Eve is the setting of a story that takes place in the middle of winter, with foggy and cold weather."

"The counting-house is Scrooge's workplace where he spends his time alone and focused on financial matters."<SEP>"The counting-house is Scrooge's workplace where he spends his time alone, focused on financial matters."

"Nephew is a character who tries to engage with his uncle on Christmas, despite the uncle's traditional views."<SEP>"The nephew of Scrooge represents a warm and joyful character who contrasts with the cold Scrooge."<SEP>"The nephew of Scrooge represents the contrast to Scrooge, showing warmth and joy at Christmas time."<SEP>"The nephew seeks to engage with his uncle, Scrooge, on Christmas traditions and practices."

"A festive event with positive intentions but also potential social implications."<SEP>"Christmas is a festive event that evokes mixed feelings; it can be seen as an occasion to pay bills, find oneself older or richer, and balance one's books."

"Scrooge's uncle is a character who tries to maintain traditional Christmas values while respecting Scrooge's financial decisions."<SEP>"Uncle is Scrooge's relative who wishes to maintain Christmas traditions but also respects Scrooge's financial decisions."
"A clerk in the tank, seen as someone not actively participating in the festive spirit."
"Christmas-time is described as a time when people are generous and open-minded towards others."

"Reference to Parliament as a possible place for political engagement, but not directly linked to Scrooge's nephew's actions."<SEP>"Reference to Parliament as an institution, not directly connected with the nephew's actions on Christmas."
"Portrayed as a character who, despite having two kindred spirits enter their office, still holds negative views towards others with different beliefs about Christmas."
"A clerk who, despite being seen as someone not actively participating in the festive spirit, involuntarily applauds during Scrooge's interactions with the nephew on Christmas."
"Mr. Scrooge is a character with miserly traits, characterized by his refusal to provide help to others during Christmas."
"The gentleman offers assistance and support for the poor during the festive season."
"Liberality is a word that Mr. Scrooge frowns upon, indicating he disapproves of it or views it negatively."
"The Poor refers to destitute people who suffer during the Christmas season and require help from Scrooge and others."
"Prisons are mentioned as places where 'many thousands' suffer, suggesting they are inadequate for housing those in need."
"The Union Workhouses are a place where people can find comfort and sustenance during the time of scarcity and difficulty."
"God represents divine blessing and good wishes for all people, symbolizing kindness."
"Scrooge's Office refers to the workplace where Scrooge and his clerk work, symbolizing a place of dreary existence due to Scrooge’s miserly nature."

nodes.id: BOB CRATCHIT AND EBENEZER SCROOGE'S PAST
nodes.description: "The ghost shows things from Bob Cratchit and Ebenezer Scrooge's past."
"The uncle attempts to engage with his nephew about Christmas traditions, but the nephew has a different perspective on how they should be observed."

edges.target: FIRST PUBLICATION OF A CHRISTMAS CAROL

edges.target: BOB CRATCHIT AND EBENEZER SCROOGE'S PAST
edges.description: "The ghost shows things from Bob Cratchit and Ebenezer Scrooge's past."
"Marley serves as a cautionary figure to Scrooge, embodying the consequences of not taking life seriously."
"The metaphorical use of 'door-nail' emphasizes the permanent nature of Marley's death and Scrooge's status as a firm owner."
"Marley acts as an analog to Hamlet's father, warning Scrooge about the potential consequences of his own actions."
"While Marley is dead, he represents the traditional values of Scrooge's business and partnership."
"While Marley is dead he represents the traditional values of Scrooge’s business and partnership with him."
"Scrooge receives his nephew's greeting during Christmas Eve, showing the stark contrast between their attitudes towards Christmas."
"Scrooge resents the festive spirit and values work over celebration."
"Scrooge refuses time off for Christmas Eve celebrations, reflecting his cold attitude towards festive occasions."

"The old sinner works in a counting-house, indicating his profession but also highlighting his solitary existence."<SEP>"The old sinner works in the counting-house, indicating his professional setting but also highlighting his solitary existence."

"The old sinner is unable to enjoy the holiday spirit due to being in a professional setting and lack of warmth at home."<SEP>"The old sinner is unable to enjoy the holiday spirit due to his professional environment and lack of warmth at home."
"The nephew seeks to engage with his uncle Scrooge on Christmas traditions, showing a desire for understanding and connection."
"The uncle tries to maintain traditional Christmas values while respecting Scrooge's financial decisions."
"The uncle attempts to engage with his nephew about Christmas traditions, but the nephew has a different perspective on how they should be observed."
"Mr. Scrooge asks about prisons, showing his lack of concern for their inhabitants who suffer in times of need."
"Mr. Scrooge does not provide help to the poor, highlighting his miserly nature."
